bioghist.p: Marguerite de Angeli (1889-1987) was a bestselling author and illustrator of children's books including the 1950 Newbery Award winning book The Door in the Wall. She wrote and illustrated twenty-eight of her own books, and illustrated more than three dozen books and numerous magazine stories and articles for other authors. She was twice named a Caldecott Honor Book illustrator, first in 1945 for Yonie Wondernose and again in 1955 for Book of Nursery and Mother Goose Rhymes and she received a 1957 Newbery Honor mention for Black Fox of Lorne. In her illustrations de Angeli employed a number of different media, including charcoal, pen and ink, lithograph (only in earliest work), oils, and watercolors. Her works explored and depicted the rich cultural diversity of common people in America. Many of her books were set in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of drafts, galley proofs, and mockups, for several of De Angeli's published works. Other materials in the collection include: correspondence with family, friends, readers, and others interested in her work; a scrapbook and magazine clippings with illustrations by De Angeli; and illustrations from The Old Testament. Additional materials include a collection of clippings, photographs and other items related to De Angeli collected by the Free Library.
